Low-temperature oxidation represents an economically efficient way to convert spinoff hydrocarbons such as butadiene into nontoxic species. This study investigates the catalytic oxidation of 1,3-butadiene over ceria-supported niobium oxide, exploring the synthesis routes and catalytic performances. Experimental characterization techniques, including X-ray spectroscopy and diffractometry, microscopy, and other micro-characterisations, elucidate the structure of the catalysts as corroborated by the density functional theory (DFT) method. DFT calculations constructed the underlying oxidative reaction mechanisms that ensue through accessible activation energies in steps that feature subsequent CC bond fissions, H transfer reactions, CO desorption, and formation of CO2 molecules. The results show that, the niobium oxide assumes mainly the form of Nb2O5 on ceria supports, and plays a significant role in switching the physicochemical nature of ceria and the resulting catalysts. Despite a relatively lower surface area, the NbO x /CeO2 catalysts exhibit superior performances in the conversion of butadiene compared to pure ceria. The catalyst prepared with 10 wt.% of Nb has the best catalytic performance with 82% conversion of butadiene, highest reaction rate, and selectivity towards CO2 of 95% at the temperature range of 300 – 400 °C and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 34,600 h−1. Obtained results entail practical environmental implications in the catalytic destruction of stable hydrocarbon species. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Low-temperature oxidation 1,3-butadiene Catalyst Ceria support Niobium oxide 1 Introduction 1,3-butadiene (C4H6), a colourless diolefin, forms as an undesirable chemical by-product with adverse effects that span catalyst poisoning and butene feed contamination in olefins petrochemical processes. About 95% of butadiene is obtained as a side product of steam cracking of paraffinic hydrocarbons, especially in ethylene production worldwide [1–3]. The international agency for research on cancer (IARC) has categorised this flammable gas in Group 1 human carcinogenic agents, with the propensity to causes genetic defects, respiratory and dermal problems in case of repeated exposure [4,5]. Catalytic oxidation has become a viable method to convert hazardous chemical into the environmentally less toxic species [6–10]. There are numerous studies investigating the catalytic oxidation of hydrocarbons, most notably alkanes [11–16]; for instance, by (supported) metal oxides [17–21], including, SiO2 [22–24], Al2O3 [25–27], TiO2 [28–30], ZnO [31–33], and ZrO2 [34–36]. Ceria (i.e., cerium (IV) oxide, CeO2) exhibit excellent attributes in oxidation processes [37–43], due to desirable characteristics such as facile Ce4+/Ce3+redox shift [44,45], profound oxygen storage capacity [46,47], and surface/subsurface defects [48,49]. Comparatively higher catalytic activity of ceria-supported catalysts originates from the strong metal-support interactions, which contributes to an enhanced dissociation of species over catalyst surfaces [50,51]. A consensus of opinions indicates that trace metal elements improve the catalytic activity of ceria, in applications pertinent to low-temperature combustion of hydrocarbons [52–59]. A few critical remarks could be drawn to inform the development of new catalysts. Firstly, the non-stoichiometry form of CeO2- x in the presence of trace metals (e.g., Pd) and high support porosity favor the catalytic activity of ceria-supported catalysts [60]. Secondly, in addition to the critical role of trace metal (e.g., Pt) active sites, ceria-based (e.g., Pt/CeO2) catalysts display relatively higher oxygen storage capacity than those of other types of supports (e.g., Pt/Al2O3) [61]. Thirdly, increasing the ionic conductivity by incorporating additional trace elements, e.g., in Pt/(Ce y Gd z )O2- x catalysts, decreases the rate of carbon formation over catalyst surface [62]. Furthermore, depositing clusters of metal oxides on ceria remains another effective way of improving the catalytic oxidative activity of ceria. The target here is to enhance the reducibility, among other properties [63,64]. Pengpanich et al. [65] have shown that incorporation of ZrO2 into ceria increased the redox properties of the mixed-matrix catalyst. In this case, the authors found Ce0 . 75Zr0 . 25O2 to be the most effective catalyst for methane oxidation. Further increment in the Zr ratio decreases the catalytic activity due to reduced surface reducibility. Moreover, one can achieve enhanced performances by tuning the catalyst to ensure relatively higher oxygen mobility and crystal defects as demonstrated by ionic Cu species in Cu-doped CeO2-ZrO2 mixed matrix for alkanes oxidation [66], and limiting the relative amount of ceria support [67]. This work focuses on novel ceria-supported niobium oxide catalysts. Traces of niobium and its oxide forms can act as an active agent or a promoter in heterogeneous catalysis due to the ability to form surface niobium oxide over-layer as a result of strong NbO x -support interactions [68], catalytically enhanced redox properties [69], and the formation of strong acidic sites [70]. Moreover, the d orbital's electrons in niobium oxide catalyst is proven to possess a key role in the dissociation of adsorbed molecules [71]. Moreover, it has been found that presence of niobium in its highest oxidation form contributes to the catalytic stability during the reaction [72–74]. However, the performance and efficiency of Nb in some ceria-based catalyst remains unknown, especially towards low-temperature oxidation of stable hydrocarbon species such as butadiene. Therefore, in conjunction with the density functional theory (DFT) method, this paper explores the synthesis routes of NbO x /CeO2 catalysts, characterises the catalysts' physicochemical nature, and measure the respective catalytic performances in the low-temperature surface-assisted combustion of 1,3-butadiene. The latter serves as a model compound for the content of unsaturated hydrocarbons that emit in considerable quantities in thermal processes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ceria-supported niobium catalysts were prepared via the incipient wetness impregnation method as explained elsewhere [75]. Appropriate amount of ammonium niobate (V) oxalate hydrate (C4H4NNbO9, Sigma-Aldrich, >99%) corresponding to 5, 10, 15, and 20 wt.% of Nb in catalysts’ preparation matrix was initially dissolved in deionised water under vigorous stirring at 70 °C. Once dissolved, the support, i.e., CeO2 micro-powder (<5 μm, Sigma-Aldrich, >99%), was added gradually to the solution while being stirred at ambient temperature. Then, the precursor was dried overnight at 100 °C in an oven prior to calcination in static air at 400 °C for 4 h. The calcination temperature of 400 °C represents the optimum condition for sintering/surface area [76]. We labelled the catalysts as Nb-5, Nb-10, Nb-15, and Nb-20 to reflect the weight percent of Nb in the starting matrix. For instance, Nb-5 denotes NbO x /CeO2 catalyst that was prepared with 5 wt.% of Nb. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 X-ray spectroscopy and diffractometry GBC EMMA X-Ray diffractometer recorded the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of catalyst samples with Cu Kα radiation operating at 35 kV and 28 mA while employing a low-background sample holder for better accuracy. The patterns were collected in a 2θ range from 10° to 90°, with step size and scanning speed of 0.02 and 2° min−1, respectively. For the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis, the powder samples were initially pressed into pellets with a shallow thickness (∼500 μm), placed in a high-pressure cell connected to the analysis chamber, and cooled down by an inert gas flow. After the pre-treatment, the samples were transferred to the highly evacuated analysis chamber (background vacuum of around 2 × 10−9 mbar). ESCALAB250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, UK) recorded the XPS spectra with the AlK α radiation of 1486.68 eV and a spot size of 500 μm. The mono-chromated X-ray source was operated at 160 W (14.5 kV, 11 mA) and the photoelectron take-off angle was set to 90° Avantage software was used to obtain the data considering the binding energy reference of 284.8 eV (C 1 s peak for adventitious hydrocarbon). 2.2.2 Microscopy and elemental analyses The morphology and texture of the samples were inspected by LEO 1450 VP scanning electron microscope (SEM) with secondary electron imaging. The samples were sputtered for 70 s by Au sputter coater before the characterization. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis was performed to confirm the presence of intended elements in the catalyst matrix. For EDS measurements, the samples were coated with carbon, and backscatter electrons enabled the compositional imaging. 2.2.3 BET measurements The surface area of prepared catalysts was measured by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method via N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at −196 °C using a SAPA 2010 (Micromeritics Instrument) gas adsorption device. Approximately 0.5 g of catalysts samples were degassed in vacuum at 300 °C overnight to exclude pre-adsorbed components before measurements. The specific surface area was then determined from the linear portion of the BET plot. Pore size distribution was calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method afterwards. 2.2.4 ICP-MS Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was carried out using a Thermo Scientific iCAP RQ instrument to identify the real content of niobium in the catalyst matrix. Initially, appropriate amount of samples were digested into the nitric acid solution followed by dilution to the desired concentrations of 500 ppb. An aqueous nitric acid solution of 2 wt.% was also used as the blank solution as well as rinsing. The spectrometer was then calibrated with injection of 200, 400 and 600 ppb of standard Nb containing solutions and drawing absorbance vs. concentration graph before quantifications. 2.3 Catalytic run Catalytic oxidation of butadiene was carried out in a tubular quartz reactor, housed in an electrically heated furnace, at atmospheric pressure within a temperature range of 100 – 400 °C with 50 °C intervals. Digital mass flow controllers adjusted the flow of butadiene (0.5% C4H6, balanced with He, supplied by BOC Australia) and synthetic air by maintaining the stoichiometric ratio for butadiene combustion (C4H6/ air: 70/10). Catalyst (1 g) was placed in the middle of the reactor and immobilised with ultra-pure quartz wool. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of the reactants amounted to 34,600 h−1. The butadiene conversion (X) and reaction rate were calculated from the following equations, respectively [77]: (1) X = C A 0 − C A f C A 0 × 100 (2) − r A = F A 0 × x A W (3) − r A = k C A where C A 0 and C A f are initial and final concentrations of butadiene, respectively. The term − r A represents the rate of the reaction based on mass unit (mol• s −1• g −1 cat ), F A 0 denotes initial molar flow rate (mol•s−1), and W corresponds to the catalyst weight (gcat). The rate constant (k) was then calculated by considering the pseudo-first order reaction as shown in Eq. (3) [77]. 2.4 Computational DFT details Density functional theory (DFT) has been widely utilized to comprehend the electronic structures and catalyzed reactions by ceria [78,79]. Configurations of defected ceria surfaces are normally optimised in the presence of oxygen vacancies to mimic operational conditions in real experimental scenarios [80,81]. Moreover, ability of the ions to form strong associations with either electron bearing species or oxygen vacancies is among the most important parameters in efficiency of doped ceria surfaces. Such aspects are best to be addressed via DFT computations [82,83]. The CASTEP code executes [84] structural optimizations, energy estimations, and constructs surface-assisted mechanisms based on the generalized gradient approximation (GGA-LDA) [85]. The “on the fly pseudopotential” accounts for the interaction between the valence electron and the ion core. The energy of the convergence tolerance, maximum force, maximum stress, and maximum displacement were set to 0.0001 eV/atom, 0.03 eV/Å, 0.05 GPa and 0.001 Å, correspondingly. To describe the on-site Coulomb interactions for the Nb 4d and Ce 4f orbitals, effective Hubbard U parameters of 3.0 and 4.5 eV were employed, respectively. This choice of U value follows optimized values in theoretical investigations against band gaps of CeO2 [86] and Nb2O5 [87], respectively. The plane wave cutoff energy attained a value of 400 eV and a κ-point automatic sampling of 3 × 3 × 1 was generated by the Monkhorst-Pack scheme. Transition states were located using the linear synchronous and quadratic synchronous transit LST/QST method as implemented in the CASTEP code [88]. The considered structure comprises a 2 × 2 unit-cell and involves three oxygen atomic layers. A test on one structure (M1) using higher cutoff (500 eV) and five oxygen atomic layer, has changed its binding energy by only 4%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD analysis Fig. 1 shows that the XRD patterns of the NbO x /CeO2 catalysts are identical to that of pure ceria [89]. In other words, the diffraction lines corresponding to the Nb or and oxides of niobium are not observed. The dominance of support diffraction peaks has also been observed in previous studies [90–92]. This similarity can be attributed to the relatively larger size of ceria particles compared to Nb species. Moreover, this indicates the high dispersion of niobium over ceria surface [93]. These resulted patterns suggest that the particle sizes associated with Nb species on oxide support are too small (<5 nm) to be detected by XRD [94,95]. The relative shifts in the corresponding 2θ values of (hkl) planar peaks of ceria for supported niobium oxide catalysts could be attributed to the reduction in lattice constants with respect to pure CeO2 [96]. Table 1 depicts the decreasing trend of lattice constants for the (111) plane in ceria which can be associated with all other existing planes as well. As observed, the catalyst with the highest Nb content incurs a 2.7% decrease in lattice constants relative to pristine ceria. The relatively smaller ionic radius of Nb(V) ions (0.69 Å) [97], compared those of Ce(IV) (0.94 Å) [98] in the support lattice [99], can explain such reduction in lattice constants. 3.1.2 XPS analysis Fig. 2 compares the XPS spectra of ceria and Nb-10 catalysts, considering the orbitals of the atoms in the corresponding matrix (Ce 3d, O 1 s, and Nb 3d). As can be seen (Fig. 2a), both catalysts exhibit peaks at binding energies of 915, 910, 900, 890, and 880 eV, which indicates the presence of cerium species in the stoichiometric form of Ce(IV), i.e., the highest corresponding oxidation state [100,101]. Moreover, peaks at around 905 and 885 eV binding energies are assigned to the Ce(III) [102]. The presence of the latter (i.e., 885 eV) in both catalysts spectra illustrates the switchable nature of cerium oxidation states as expected [103]. The Ce(III) peak at 905 eV is merely observed for Nb-10, representing higher relative abundance of Ce(III) compared to that of pure ceria. This may directly be attributed to the fact that incorporation of Nb species alters the oxidation state of Ce, leading to the creation of defects in the oxide structure and thus ceria non-stoichiometry as observed in other investigations [104,105]. The major O 1 s peak (Fig. 2b) for pure ceria catalyst is observed at 529.2 eV illustrating presence of oxygen in its highest oxidation state in stoichiometric ceria (CeO2) [106]. On the other hand, the O 1 s major peak for Nb-10 at 530.3 eV is attributed to the oxygen in its similar oxidation state, but in non-stoichiometric ceria (Ce2O3). Besides, minor peaks at around 531–533 eV depict the presence of surface hydroxyl groups for both catalysts [107,108]. The shift in the O 1 s spectrum of Nb-10 catalyst compared to that of pure ceria can be attributed to changes in valence charge due to electron transfer between the active metal oxide and the supporting oxide. Such changes will result in structural modifications of ceria support due to presence of an active metal oxide [109]. The major peaks at binding energies of 210 and 207 eV (Fig. 2c) indicate the presence of niobium in the form of Nb(V), which is at its highest oxidation state [110,111]. It is inferred that niobium forms an oxide form of Nb2O5 over the ceria surface in Nb-10. So, the Nb-incorporated catalyst encompasses oxides forms as Nb2O5, CeO2, and Ce2O3, while the pure ceria is limited to the two latter forms of oxides. 3.1.3 SEM and EDS analyses SEM images and EDS spectra of pure ceria and Nb2O5/CeO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The morphology of the catalysts gradually changes with increment of niobium species in the matrix. For pure ceria, inter-connected pores with the comparatively oriented structure are dominant; however, the pore volume marginally seems to decrease for Nb incorporated catalysts. Commencing from Nb-5 with the lowest niobium content, the catalyst surface gradually becomes more compact for higher Nb loadings. For the Nb-20 catalyst, the closely compact structure of pores is clearly observed. The reason for these changes can be attributed to the interactions of incorporated species with metal oxide support which has also been reported in previous researches [112,113]. The EDS analysis also ascertains the presence of Nb species in the catalyst matrix. According to the spectra of ceria and Nb-10 EDS, the Ce and O are atoms are dominantly present in both spectra representative of ceria support as the base component of the catalysts. In addition to the Ce and O peaks respectively at 4–6 keV and 0.5 keV [114,115], the Nb-10 catalyst shows Nb Lα single peak at around 2 keV [116,117]. 3.1.4 BET measurements Table 2 lists the BET measurement results for the prepared catalysts. As observed, the surface area gradually decreases with increment in Nb content. While neatly calcined ceria possesses a surface area of 65.68 m2 g−1, it is about 25 m2 g−1 for the catalyst with 20% Nb. This downward trend with an increase in Nb loading could be attributed to the partial destruction of the support or blockage of the pore entrances [118]. Fractions of the niobium species are distributed within the pores or confined in blind pores. The remaining portions also occupy the external surface of the support [119]. Thus, the total pore volume decreases with an increase in niobium content which was also observed in SEM images. 3.1.5 ICP-MS Table 3 compares the theoretical and experimental niobium contents in the catalysts structures. ICP-MS revealed that the niobium content corresponds to the theoretical one within the experimental error. As observed in Table 3, the atomic percentage of niobium was gradually increased in the prepared catalysts. The Nb content in the catalysts was approximately equal to the expected ratio within the experimental error of ±0.10. 3.2 Catalytic activity and reaction kinetics The catalytic tests reveal that butadiene conversion is highly dependent on the niobium content in the catalyst matrix (Fig. 4 a). Pure calcined ceria catalyst shows poor conversion of butadiene. On the other hand, all the Nb incorporated catalysts exhibit relatively better performance than intact support. While the highest conversion for Nb-5 catalyst is well under 10%, it reaches around 82% for Nb-10 catalyst at 400 °C; however, it decreases with the further increment of Nb in the catalyst matrix. The improved performance stems from active Nb(V) oxide [120,121] sites as well as from the vacant sites in partially reduced ceria [122,123]. In other words, the redox active linkages of Ce-O-Ce and Ce-O-Nb are capable of generating more oxygen vacancies which contribute to a more facile oxidation of the reactant over the catalyst surface [124,125]. However, since the incorporation of NbO x clusters decreases the surface area of the catalysts, the catalytic performance begins to decline at some point. It could be implied from the butadiene conversion results that the presence of niobium up to 10 wt.% moderately decreases the effective surface area for the oxidation. With the further increment of Nb species, the decreasing surface area overweighs the abundance of active sites on the surface; thus, up to specific content, niobium increases the butadiene conversion but its further incorporation adversely affects the reaction. The results show significant performance of Nb2O5/CeO2 catalysts. A few investigations have addressed catalytic oxidation of 1,3-butadiene over various catalysts formulations [126,127]. Thus, we ae now in a position to compare the catalytic capacity of the Nb2O5/CeO2 formulations with other metal oxides. In a purely gas phase reaction, the 1,3-butadiene reactant converted up to 90% at relatively much higher temperature ranges (900–1000 °C) [128,129]. Previous studies on the catalytic oxidation of butadiene at 400 °C reported relatively lower selectivity (53%) and conversion (60%) into organic compounds on MoO3-TiO2 catalyst [130]. Similarly, V2O5/Al2O3/Al-coated catalyst [131] was also applied for partial oxidation of butadiene at a constant temperature of 320 °C. The selectivity towards organic products (maleic anhydride as major component and mixture of other product) and conversion, however, were not found to be equally high. With a low butadiene conversion of 15%, the catalyst was much selective toward the formation of COx species (70%). On the contrary, it dropped to 56% for the very high butadiene conversion (96%). In another study [132], its oxidation was investigated over VMoO catalyst surface prepared via sol-gel technique from MoO3 and V2O5. The catalysts were mainly selective towards CO x (∼45%) at 300 °C as the highest temperature; however, the highest butadiene conversion was reported to be very low (∼5%) at the same temperature. Catalyst with desirable characteristics is expected to have favourable selectivity with a relatively high conversion. The Nb-10 catalyst in this study shows that both conversion and selectivity to be simultaneously high, especially at the temperature range of 300–400 °C. Niobium loading in NbO x /CeO2 generally contributes to the switchable cation exchange nature of ceria [133]. Highly dispersed Nb species in the aforementioned matrix are capable of formation of more defects and thus higher activity [134]. The adsorption sites from NbO x in ceria are also found to possess more adsorption capacity at higher temperature due to the more stabilised nature [135]. Unlike butadiene, niobium modified ceria catalysts have been applied for oxidation of other compounds. For instance, benzene combustion over Au/Nb-CeO2 [136] showed that an increase in temperature has a direct effect on the catalytic activity of Nb modified catalysts where the highest benzene conversion was attained at 350–400 °C. The interactions of niobium oxide and ceria [137] have also been noted as a key factor in improved oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) over Cu/CeO2 Nb2O5 catalysts. Presence of Nb2O5 in the ceria-niobia support [138] was reported to enhance catalytic activity and stability due to the lower coverage of carbonate species in CO oxidation. Niobium-doped ceria catalysts are also capable of carbon deposits oxidation at relatively lower temperatures under oxidizing conditions [139]. The kinetics of the catalytic reactions has also been investigated. An increase in reaction temperature resulted in a higher butadiene conversion. The highest reaction rate at 400 °C for Nb-10 amounts to 530.82 mol s−1 g−1 cat which is much higher compared to other catalysts with the following order for butadiene conversion: Nb-10> Nb-15> Nb-20> Nb-5> CeO2. Table 4 shows the trend in rate constants for all catalysts prepared in this study. The performance of niobium oxide ceria catalysts is related to the simultaneous effects of ceria and niobium in the matrix. Compared to other metal oxides, ceria significantly improves the catalytic activity, resulting from its oxygen storage property when used as a support for trace metals. The redox properties of ceria cause the very strong so-called metal-support interactions. This has been rationalised based on the fact that the formed oxygen vacancies on the surface bind the corresponding adsorbate, leading to easier reactant dissociation over the surface [140,141]. Improved active sites resulting from surface/subsurface defects and strong metallic interactions between catalysts and support are key factors contributing to the desired activity of ceria-supported catalysts [142]. The selectivity of catalysts was also measured towards CO2 and CO (Fig. 4b). It was found that all catalysts were more selective towards CO2 rather than CO. Presence of Nb in the catalyst structure led to the formation of a higher CO2 selective catalysts. Due to the nature of the reaction, catalysts with higher activity at lower temperatures are thermodynamically favoured for CO2 production. The CO2 selectivity for ceria was around 65 to 70%, while the catalysts with the highest Nb content showed the highest selectivity of 95% at 400 °C. 3.3 A mechanistic insight The profound catalytic activity of the Nb-10 configuration can be assigned to the improved electronic properties in reference to pure ceria. The density of states curves (DOS) plotted in Fig. 5 indicates a significant narrowing of the band gap of pure ceria by 1.42 eV for Nb incorporated ceria configuration. In the CeO2 (111) surface decorated with Nb, a niobium atom occupies a cerium atom site in the first layer. Our finding herein is consistent with the general consensus that doped ceria nanocrystals often exhibit dramatic band narrowing, even at minute loads of added metals [143,144]. While the considered surface in the calculations may not fully reflect the actual complex structure of Nb2O5/CeO2 catalyst utilized in this work, the clear shift toward a metallic behavior is in accordance with the reported low-temperature oxidation capacity. It is well-documented that catalytic activity of ceria-based materials rests on the facile creation of oxygen vacant sites and that atomic dopants reducing the required energy to remove a lattice oxygen from the surface [145]. Herein, we find that evolution of an oxygen molecule from the Nb-doped surface requires 85 kcal/mol while leaving two oxygen vacant sites. This value is 7 kcal/mol lower than the corresponding energy in case of a neat CeO2(111) surface [146,147]. Fig. 6 illustrates atomic charges as a complementary to the aforementioned discussions. Accordingly, Nb-O surface bonds (Fig. 6b) bear lower ionic character than that of Ce-O (Fig. 6a). As Fig. 6c portrays, Nb atoms are surrounded by sites with lower charge density when compared with the Ce atoms. Fig. 7 depicts constructed mechanism for the oxidative decomposition the 1,3-butadiene over the Nb2O5/CeO2 (i.e., CeO2(111)_Nb catalyst). A structure with a vacant O* site was considered. The 1,3-butadiene molecule binds to the surface via forming a bridge between its outer unsaturated carbon atom and surface Nb and O atoms. The binding energy amounts to ∼28 kcal/mol (the intermediate M1 in Fig. 7). The first step characterizes a surface-mediated fission of a CC bond through the transition structure TS1 through an accessible activation energy of 28.2 kcal/mol. Considering the pure ceria surface, the corresponding energy barrier for the opening step attains a slightly higher value of 37.2 kcal/mol. The catalytic activity of the Nb2O5/CeO2 catalyst can also be assigned to a relatively facile scission of the first CC bonds (in addition to a lower endothermicity for evolution of oxygen from the surface). In the produced intermediate M2, the two hydrocarbon fragments are attached to the surface O* site. A second fission of a CC bond generates an adsorbed C2H4 adduct (product with all component atoms) through the transition state TS2 (30.3 kcal/mol). The following steps encompass H transfer from the H2CO* surface group into Nb* and O* sites through a relatively considerable activation barriers of 42.6 – 43.6 kcal/mol. In the final step, a CO molecule desorbs from the surface in a step that demands only 14.0 kcal/mol. Formation of CO2 (the final desired product) takes place via direct O abstraction from the surface by a gas-phase CO molecule. It is worth noticing that a CO2 molecule could also form through two adsorbed oxygen and CO molecules. 4 Conclusion Overall, this study provided an insightful outlook into effect of niobium loading on ceria support for applications related to the low-temperature oxidation of hydrocarbons. In this regards, different Nb2O5/CeO2 catalysts as well as pure ceria catalysts, were prepared, characterised, and tested for 1,3-butadiene oxidation. In an accord with other literature findings, oxidation reactions of unsaturated hydrocarbons mainly ensue over the vacant sites of ceria. It is concluded that the presence of niobium in the catalyst matrix leads to a significant improvement in catalytic activity via its contribution to the formation of surface defects. Through DFT calculations, we have shown that catalytic capacity of the Nb2O5/CeO2 catalysts stems from electronic attributes pertinent to a lower band gap and ionicity of Nb-O bonds, in reference to pure ceria. The Nb-10 catalyst proved to be the most effective supported catalyst in oxidation of the 1,3-butadiene molecule. Such profound activity originates from a balanced compromise between improved concentration of active sites and decreasing surface area. coredata.dc:description: Low-temperature oxidation represents an economically efficient way to convert spinoff hydrocarbons such as butadiene into nontoxic species. This study investigates the catalytic oxidation of 1,3-butadiene over ceria-supported niobium oxide, exploring the synthesis routes and catalytic performances. Experimental characterization techniques, including X-ray spectroscopy and diffractometry, microscopy, and other micro-characterisations, elucidate the structure of the catalysts as corroborated by the density functional theory (DFT) method. DFT calculations constructed the underlying oxidative reaction mechanisms that ensue through accessible activation energies in steps that feature subsequent CC bond fissions, H transfer reactions, CO desorption, and formation of CO2 molecules. The results show that, the niobium oxide assumes mainly the form of Nb2O5 on ceria supports, and plays a significant role in switching the physicochemical nature of ceria and the resulting catalysts. Despite a relatively lower surface area, the NbO x /CeO2 catalysts exhibit superior performances in the conversion of butadiene compared to pure ceria. The catalyst prepared with 10 wt.% of Nb has the best catalytic performance with 82% conversion of butadiene, highest reaction rate, and selectivity towards CO2 of 95% at the temperature range of 300 – 400 °C and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 34,600 h−1. Obtained results entail practical environmental implications in the catalytic destruction of stable hydrocarbon species.
coredata.dc:title: Ceria-supported niobium oxide catalyst for low-temperature oxidation of 1,3-butadiene
